quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Snyk makes it easy for developers to catch security issues in their code, and there's a lot to learn from how Snyk got started.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a clear, developer-centric value proposition—useful as a model for positioning and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It started through product-led growth, evolved into product-led sales, was very community driven, and it was also laser-focused on developers which has become one of the most lucrative markets to go after.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a growth evolution sequence (PLG → product-led sales) plus the strategic bet on community and a specific buyer/user segment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we cover how the founders have Snyk out their first a hundred users, what they got wrong when they tried to monetize early on, when they hired their first marketing and sales people, how they structured and grew their growth and product teams, what they figured out about what should go into freemium and what shouldn't, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals several practitioner-relevant levers—early user acquisition, monetization timing, hiring sequencing, team structure, and freemium packaging decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Ben’s career path into developer tooling
quotes.text: This was all pre-Agile, but that whole space of developer tooling, engineering tooling, it was something I just felt naturally drawn to and it's where I've really specialized through my whole career.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights the value of leaning into a clear domain specialization over time (developer/engineering tooling) as a career strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Ben’s career path into developer tooling
quotes.text: I actually joined that company as a solutions engineer, so lots of demos and so on. I was really close to the product team, but also speaking with customers every day which as is quite common I think was my path into products there.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete pathway into product: roles that combine proximity to product teams with daily customer contact.

quotes.topic_title: Ben’s career path into developer tooling
quotes.text: I actually, I learned a ton of useful stuff there, but also that I had a strong preference for working in smaller, fast-growing orgs verse 350,000 people [inaudible 00:06:55].
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A candid, experience-based tradeoff between learning in big companies and personal fit/impact in smaller fast-growing orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Ben’s career path into developer tooling
quotes.text: Stayed with them for three years through several raises and a period of really fast growth before finally joining Snyk to build out our growth organization and lead our developer experience initiatives.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Shows a repeatable pattern: using high-growth environments to build expertise in growth and developer experience, then applying it at the next stage.

quotes.topic_title: What Snyk does and company scale
quotes.text: The developer security company, we make it ridiculously easy for developers and their teams to improve their security posture while still moving fast.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Clear product positioning that pairs security outcomes with developer velocity—useful as a guiding principle for developer-first PLG products.

quotes.topic_title: What Snyk does and company scale
quotes.text: So, Snyk can find and automatically fixed vulnerabilities in code, open source dependencies, containers, infrastructure and cloud configurations, and all underpinned by the best security intelligence data in the market with a laser focus on developer experiences, which is why we're, we are really different.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of differentiated scope (end-to-end coverage) plus a wedge (developer experience) that practitioners can emulate in messaging and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: What Snyk does and company scale
quotes.text: We were founded in 2015, last valuation after our Series F was at 8.6 billion.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Concrete scale metric that anchors the company’s growth trajectory and credibility in the market.

quotes.topic_title: What Snyk does and company scale
quotes.text: We're securing the software of millions of developers now, well over 2,000 paying customers, now around 1300 people of which are around 500 in R and D with nearly 70 folks in our product org.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Specific operating metrics (customers, headcount, R&D and product org size) that help practitioners benchmark org design at scale.

quotes.topic_title: What Snyk does and company scale
quotes.text: these were all things that if you create a Venn diagram of all the things that I'm really interested in professionally, super interested in, super exciting to me, then kind of Snyk ended up in the middle of it.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A simple mental model (Venn diagram fit) for evaluating roles/companies based on overlapping personal and market drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Founders’ early PLG insight and first users
quotes.text: So, PLG or bottom up and security, these were never words that were known to have been spoken together in a single sentence, right?
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights the contrarian starting point: applying bottom-up/product-led growth in a traditionally top-down security market.

quotes.topic_title: Founders’ early PLG insight and first users
quotes.text: They started with a really narrow, early focus. It was a single persona, single context, single use case, and what that meant for Snyk was developers building applications using Node.js who wanted to ensure that the open source dependencies they were pulling into their apps were secure.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A crisp focus framework (single persona/context/use case) that practitioners can apply to find initial traction.

quotes.topic_title: Founders’ early PLG insight and first users
quotes.text: The average software application today is at least 75% of open source libraries and components.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies why open-source dependency security is a high-leverage wedge.

quotes.topic_title: Founders’ early PLG insight and first users
quotes.text: And the question that they repeatedly posed to the community was do you have known vulnerabilities in your apps, and Snyk was there to help them answer that question.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Shows an actionable community-led acquisition tactic: a simple, repeatable hook framed as a question.

quotes.topic_title: Founders’ early PLG insight and first users
quotes.text: I think we probably had maybe around 5,000 free users before there are any attempts at monetization.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A memorable example of prioritizing adoption and retention before monetization in a PLG motion.

quotes.topic_title: Staying narrow: depth-first to reach PMF
quotes.text: ... but narrow enough that technology wise, it meant that a product could be brought to market in a reasonable time.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for choosing an initial niche: big enough to matter, but narrow enough to ship quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Staying narrow: depth-first to reach PMF
quotes.text: But ultimately it was important because of this kind of depth verse breadth approach and that depth-first approach that Snyk took was important to be able to effectively validate the solution on the path to product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A clear framework—depth-first vs. breadth-first—for reaching PMF by validating value deeply in one ecosystem before expanding.

quotes.topic_title: Staying narrow: depth-first to reach PMF
quotes.text: A JavaScript developer just won't care if you support Golang or Rust, but will absolutely care if a key feature like automated package upgrades just isn't available for their ecosystem.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive prioritization: ecosystem-specific completeness can matter more than adding new languages or personas.

quotes.topic_title: Staying narrow: depth-first to reach PMF
quotes.text: But the key for Snyk I think was just not to go too wide, too early.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Memorable guidance to resist premature expansion and focus on nailing the initial use case first.

quotes.topic_title: Staying narrow: depth-first to reach PMF
quotes.text: And even back then the NPM, the Node Package Manager hosted around 200,000 open source packages. They were downloaded something like two and a half billion times a month by over 2 million devs.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Concrete market-sizing data showing how a “narrow” focus can still be massive enough to drive growth.

quotes.topic_title: Designing growth loops into the product
quotes.text: founders really should be thinking about how their product is going to grow
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A reminder that growth mechanics should be designed intentionally, not treated as a later-stage problem after PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Designing growth loops into the product
quotes.text: founders really should have, I think, strong hypothesis around this, your risk essentially, adopting an if we build it, they'll come approach.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Pushes practitioners to explicitly model where new users will come from rather than relying on hope-based distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Designing growth loops into the product
quotes.text: understanding and being intentional about your early acquisition growth loops I think is an essential founder's responsibility. Dedicating time there to design those loops into the product, it's key.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A clear methodology: treat growth loops as a core product responsibility and build them into early iterations.

quotes.topic_title: Designing growth loops into the product
quotes.text: New users, they'll sign up for Snyk, they'll connect their GitHub accounts, Snyk will scan their code, will find vulnerabilities, will automatically create Snyk-branded pull requests to fix those vulnerabilities. Other devs in the repo will see and interact with those PRs, and some of them will follow links to Snyk, create accounts and some of them will connect their own repos, and so the loop continues.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable example of a product-led acquisition loop embedded directly in a user’s existing workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Designing growth loops into the product
quotes.text: So, company generated, company distributed content loop, it's actually really powerful for us because it's both an acquisition loop and an engagement loop.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A memorable framing of a dual-purpose loop that drives both new-user growth and ongoing product usage.

quotes.topic_title: Programmatic SEO loops: Advisor and education
quotes.text: Company generated, company distributed content loops have actually worked really well for us.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A clear, reusable growth model: create and distribute your own content loops rather than relying only on external channels.

quotes.topic_title: Programmatic SEO loops: Advisor and education
quotes.text: We build this kind of package health score, so anyone searching on Google for a package that does X, Y, Z or a specific package by name, Snyk Advisor will be right up there in terms of the search results.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete programmatic SEO tactic: generate high-intent pages around a “score” users search for, to win rankings and capture demand.

quotes.topic_title: Programmatic SEO loops: Advisor and education
quotes.text: That's a great loop. That's all kind of a programmatic asset. There are hundreds of thousands of these package pages, but they're just automatically being generated continuously.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A scalable methodology: continuously auto-generate large volumes of SEO landing pages to create a compounding acquisition loop.

quotes.topic_title: Programmatic SEO loops: Advisor and education
quotes.text: One of the things that is, again, something that's pretty different from the industry from an incumbent perspective is that we believe it's really important to democratize security education.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A contrarian positioning move: making education freely available can differentiate from incumbents and drive discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Programmatic SEO loops: Advisor and education
quotes.text: We have been building this bunch of really high quality but bite size lessons about developer security that focus on developers about security issues and vulnerabilities and we surface them. Again, they're out there in the public domain. There's no paywall to get access to those.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: An actionable content strategy: publish high-quality, bite-sized lessons with no paywall to fuel top-of-funnel growth.

quotes.topic_title: Early monetization struggles and shift to enterprise
quotes.text: Valuable product, check, strong developer user growth, check, strong retention, check, but the first self-serve monetization efforts only really saw traction with individual developers paying a hundred dollars a month.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete monetization data point: strong product metrics didn’t translate into self-serve revenue beyond individual devs.

quotes.topic_title: Early monetization struggles and shift to enterprise
quotes.text: The team dived in, they really figured out what the constraints were and through that process really learned about the importance of catering for the broader governance needs of the enterprise buyer.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Captures the key shift in buyer understanding: enterprise adoption hinges on governance requirements, not just developer love.

quotes.topic_title: Early monetization struggles and shift to enterprise
quotes.text: First, there was a need to build out table stakes features around governance at scale.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Actionable product guidance: enterprise readiness requires “table stakes” governance capabilities before scaling monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Early monetization struggles and shift to enterprise
quotes.text: It's obvious in retrospect that only supporting developers using a narrow slice of those tech stacks wasn't going to meet the needs of the security teams who were ultimately the people who were held accountable for the security of their entire application estate.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A mental model for expansion: enterprise security buyers are accountable for the whole estate, so breadth of ecosystem support matters.

quotes.topic_title: Early monetization struggles and shift to enterprise
quotes.text: At the time, the only buyers were security teams and dev first Security for the most part wasn't something that CISOs and ApSec leaders were driving.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive market insight: “developer-first security” wasn’t initially pulled by CISOs, shaping go-to-market and relationship strategy.

quotes.topic_title: From sales-required to more self-serve over time
quotes.text: What was always true though even back then was the influencing power of developers, regardless of where the buying center was.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights a durable go-to-market principle: developers can drive outcomes even when they aren’t the formal buyers.

quotes.topic_title: From sales-required to more self-serve over time
quotes.text: I think back then, yes. Now it's a very different story. We have a lot of self-serve only customers scaling pretty large, so.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive evolution: a company can start sales-led and later see meaningful large-scale self-serve growth.

quotes.topic_title: From sales-required to more self-serve over time
quotes.text: Yeah, I think it is important to acknowledge though, that the product has always played a really key part in the sales process for sure.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that even in sales-assisted motions, the product should do heavy lifting in conversion and expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Winning developers: meet them in their workflow
quotes.text: First of all, fundamentally for someone to get excited about using a product, they've got to care enough, right? They've got to have a problem that you're solving.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A simple adoption prerequisite: developer excitement follows from a problem they genuinely feel.

quotes.topic_title: Winning developers: meet them in their workflow
quotes.text: The key then is how do I make the job of being secure for these developers, as painless as it absolutely needs to be?
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Reframes security tooling success around minimizing friction for developers, not just improving security outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Winning developers: meet them in their workflow
quotes.text: And that means really meeting them where they are, integrating with their tools, finding ways to take security to them instead of trying to pull them out of their workflows.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A workflow-first mental model: adoption increases when the product comes to the developer’s existing tools.

quotes.topic_title: Winning developers: meet them in their workflow
quotes.text: Flow is just this incredibly important concept for developers and you want to strive to keep them in that flow for as long as possible.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights “protect developer flow” as a core product principle for developer-facing tools.

quotes.topic_title: Winning developers: meet them in their workflow
quotes.text: Someone can sign up for Snyk and they could theoretically be the only user of Snyk and connect their repos. All of a sudden we're protecting, securing those repos, a hundred, a thousand developers could be working in GitHub with that code, all benefiting from Snyk without necessarily needing to sign up.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete example of scaling adoption via integration: one signup can deliver value to hundreds or thousands through GitHub workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Why it felt hard early: monetization, not adoption
quotes.text: First of all, don't think the challenges were there in terms of the developer adoption.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Reframes early-stage risk: adoption can be strong while the real bottleneck is elsewhere (e.g., monetization/enterprise readiness).

quotes.topic_title: Why it felt hard early: monetization, not adoption
quotes.text: The developer adoption, the free user base was still growing at a really good pace.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights a practical signal to track in PLG: free-user momentum can validate value even before revenue scales.

quotes.topic_title: Why it felt hard early: monetization, not adoption
quotes.text: That momentum was just constantly building and it's that momentum that has ultimately fueled the sales led business as we've gone through the years.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Offers a mental model for hybrid PLG: self-serve adoption can become the engine that powers later sales-led expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Why it felt hard early: monetization, not adoption
quotes.text: But it was just those few things I think that I mentioned earlier in terms of stumbling blocks that needed to be overcome because when those first sales and marketing hires did join us and we started having conversations and we also tweaked some of the things in the product to meet, had some breadth, had some additional languages, ecosystems, building those table stakes features, then it really unlocked and it was rocket ship time from then.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Actionable playbook: pair early GTM hires with product “table stakes” (breadth, languages/ecosystems) to unlock enterprise growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why it felt hard early: monetization, not adoption
quotes.text: Sounds like the biggest issue is monetization. Can we make money doing this? Developers love it, they're using it like crazy, but will people be convinced to scale this an inside an organization and pay us a bunch of money for it?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the core PLG-to-enterprise challenge: converting grassroots usage into org-wide paid rollout.

quotes.topic_title: How Snyk formed and structured the growth org
quotes.text: I think the significant change that happened there, it was a transition from a simple freemium approach to a holistic and well-coordinated PLG strategy.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights the key shift from “freemium” as a pricing tactic to PLG as an orchestrated, cross-functional strategy.

quotes.topic_title: How Snyk formed and structured the growth org
quotes.text: The problem when starting the growth group, it was really for the most part more oriented to how we can get the flywheel spinning faster as opposed to getting it moving in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A useful diagnostic for when to form a growth org: accelerate an already-working motion rather than invent it from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: How Snyk formed and structured the growth org
quotes.text: At the beginning we just focused on acquisition and activation, intentionally deferring any investment into specific monetization initiatives around the self-serve revenue channel until we felt confident that A, we'd built the necessary growth muscles to scale, and B, we'd figured out some of the more pressing issues that were present earlier in the user journey.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A sequencing playbook: build acquisition/activation capability and fix early-journey constraints before pushing self-serve monetization.

quotes.topic_title: How Snyk formed and structured the growth org
quotes.text: When I joined, there was an inherent tension built into the system. It was particularly noticeable between R&D and the growth marketing team.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Calls out a common organizational failure mode—product/engineering vs. growth marketing tension—as a root cause of stalled execution.

quotes.topic_title: How Snyk formed and structured the growth org
quotes.text: When creating the growth group, we resolved this by ensuring that each of the growth teams were truly cross-functional in nature with everyone in each team aligned around common objectives and KPIs.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Actionable org design principle: reduce friction by building cross-functional growth pods with shared goals and metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Cross-functional growth teams and embedded marketers
quotes.text: When creating the growth group, we resolved this by ensuring that each of the growth teams were truly cross-functional in nature with everyone in each team aligned around common objectives and KPIs.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A practical operating model for reducing cross-functional friction: build truly cross-functional teams and align them on shared objectives/KPIs.

quotes.topic_title: Cross-functional growth teams and embedded marketers
quotes.text: Every team has engineers, an engineering manager, a product manager, a designer, a growth marketer, decision science support, and a basic shape of the growth teams that'll be familiar to most, but I spoke to a bunch of people over the last couple of years and I've actually learned to my surprise that inclusion of growth marketers in the product teams is not all that common.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A concrete team composition plus a counterintuitive observation that embedding growth marketers in product teams is still rare.

quotes.topic_title: Cross-functional growth teams and embedded marketers
quotes.text: It's important to have balanced teams with strong diversity across multiple vectors.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A memorable principle for team design that supports better decision-making and execution through diversity (including functional diversity).

quotes.topic_title: Cross-functional growth teams and embedded marketers
quotes.text: one of the big benefits you get is a broader pallet of ideas, but also a bigger toolbox when it comes to execution, which generally translates in an ability in a growth team for them to test and learn faster with more parallel, yet at the same time, aligned threats.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A clear mechanism for why embedded marketers help: more idea diversity + execution capacity enables faster, parallel experimentation without losing alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Cross-functional growth teams and embedded marketers
quotes.text: Having a growth marketer in an acquisition focused team led us to some lightweight experimentation on the website in creating an SEO optimized page. It was something that was really high performing, both from the perspective of traffic and conversion, but it didn't require any engineering resources to create.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A specific example showing how embedded marketers can run high-impact experiments (SEO landing pages) without consuming engineering bandwidth.

quotes.topic_title: Decision science, experimentation platform, and PLS enablement
quotes.text: Product led sales is a really important motion for us, and so taking the knowledge we have, the insight we have around behavior with the users and their teams and their companies within the product, and making that available to the GTM teams outside in smart ways, allowing them to focus on the things that are most important to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Shows a practical PLS enablement model: operationalize in-product behavioral insights for GTM prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Decision science, experimentation platform, and PLS enablement
quotes.text: And that team is also responsible for making that data available elsewhere in the organization as well.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Highlights a key responsibility of an experimentation/growth platform team: democratizing data beyond the growth org.

quotes.topic_title: Decision science, experimentation platform, and PLS enablement
quotes.text: No, but what she does do a great job of is providing the kind of continuously updated guidelines on how content should be structured to lead us to good results.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: A scalable SEO operating approach: central expertise sets evolving content structure standards rather than writing everything.

quotes.topic_title: Decision science, experimentation platform, and PLS enablement
quotes.text: Yeah, that's exactly right.
quotes.speaker: Ben Williams
quotes.context: Confirms a counterintuitive workflow implied by Lenny: engineers and PMs can produce SEO content when guided well.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a gating factor that directly impacts revenue velocity and deal progression.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable reminder for B2B teams that compliance can be a prerequisite for entering enterprise evaluations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point to benchmark automation potential for compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a specific time-to-audit improvement claim that practitioners can use to set expectations and timelines.
